transcript:
Patient: Attending the support group meeting was definitely out of my comfort zone, but I knew it was something I needed to do. When I got there, I felt really anxious and out of place at first. I kept thinking that everyone else there had their lives together and that I was the only one struggling.

Therapist: It's common to feel anxious and out of place in new social situations, especially when you're challenging long-held beliefs about yourself. The thoughts you experienced, like believing that everyone else had their lives together and that you were the only one struggling, are examples of cognitive distortions. In this case, you might have been engaging in mind reading, where you assumed you knew what others were thinking, and mental filter, where you focused on the negative aspects of the situation while filtering out the positive. Can you tell me more about how you felt in that moment and how you managed to stay for the full hour?

Patient: I felt really nervous and self-conscious. I kept thinking that people were judging me or pitying me for being there alone. But I tried to remind myself that everyone was there for a reason and that we all face challenges. I also remembered our discussions about challenging negative thoughts and trying to look at situations from different perspectives. So, I took a deep breath and tried to focus on why I was there – to connect with others and find support.

Therapist: That's a great example of using the skills we've been working on in real-time. By recognizing your negative thoughts and actively challenging them, you were able to shift your focus and stay in the situation, even though it was uncomfortable. This is a big step forward, Alex. How did you feel after the meeting was over?

Patient: I felt a sense of relief and accomplishment. I was proud of myself for pushing through the anxiety and staying for the whole meeting. I even had a few brief conversations with some of the other attendees, which felt good. It made me realize that maybe I'm not as alone as I thought I was.

Therapist: That's a wonderful insight, Alex. Connecting with others who share similar experiences can be incredibly validating and comforting. It's great that you were able to have some conversations and challenge your belief that you're alone in your struggles. As we continue to work on reframing your core belief, it's important to remember moments like this, where you've proven to yourself that you can cope with challenging situations and connect with others. Let's take a closer look at your core belief and start to explore some alternative perspectives. What are some of the thoughts or experiences that have contributed to your belief that you're fundamentally flawed or unlovable?

Patient: Well, growing up, my parents were always busy with their own problems, and I often felt like I was just in the way. I didn't get a lot of affection or praise from them, so I guess I started to believe that there was something wrong with me. And then, in my relationships, I've always been the one who gives more, and I've been left feeling unappreciated and rejected. It's hard to shake that feeling of being unworthy of love.
